questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with difficulty feeding and frequent regurgitation of milk through the nose. On examination, a midline defect in the hard and soft palate is noted. Which of the following is the most common associated anomaly in children with cleft palate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pierre Robin sequence 1. Key Features in the Scenario: o The infant presents with a midline defect in the hard and soft palate, consistent with cleft palate. o Feeding difficulties and nasal regurgitation are common in cleft palate due to lack of separation between the oral and nasal cavities. 2. Associated Anomalies: o Pierre Robin sequence is commonly associated with cleft palate and includes: o Micrognathia (small jaw) o Glossoptosis (posterior displacement of the tongue) o Cleft palate o Hearing loss (B) can occur due to eustachian tube dysfunction, but it is not the most common associated anomaly. o Congenital heart disease (A) and other anomalies are less frequently associated compared to syndromic causes like Pierre Robin sequence. 3. Management: o Address feeding issues with specialized bottles. o Surgical repair is typically performed around 9â€“12 months of age.

questions.text: A newborn is found to have a cleft palate on routine examination. The pediatrician explains that cleft palate develops due to the failure of which of the following embryological structures to fuse?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Palatal shelves 1. Embryological Basis: o The palatal shelves, which are outgrowths of the maxillary processes, normally elevate and fuse to form the hard and soft palate. o Failure of fusion of the palatal shelves leads to a cleft palate. 2. Differentiating Other Structures: o Medial nasal processes (A) and lateral nasal processes (B) are involved in the formation of the nose and upper lip. o Maxillary processes (C) contribute to the upper jaw and anterior part of the palate but do not directly cause cleft palate if they fail to fuse. 3. Clinical Significance: o Understanding embryology helps guide the timing and techniques of surgical repair.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with an unrepaired cleft palate is brought to the clinic due to delayed speech development. What is the most likely speech defect in this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hypernasality 1. Key Features in the Scenario: o Cleft palate leads to velopharyngeal insufficiency, where the soft palate cannot adequately separate the oral and nasal cavities during speech. o This results in hypernasality, a nasal quality in the voice due to air escaping through the nose during speech. 2. Differential Diagnoses: o Articulation disorder (A) can occur in cleft palate but is less common than hypernasality. o Stuttering (C) are unrelated to cleft palate anatomy. o Mutism (D) is unrelated to the structural defect. 3. Management: o Surgical repair of the palate and speech therapy are essential to correct the defect and improve speech quality.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is concerned about the risk of cleft palate in her unborn child. Which of the following factors is most strongly associated with the development of cleft palate in the fetus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anticonvulsant use 1. Risk Factors for Cleft Palate: o Anticonvulsant medications, such as phenytoin or valproic acid, are strongly associated with craniofacial abnormalities, including cleft lip and palate. Other risk factors: o Maternal smoking (A): Associated with cleft lip more than cleft palate. o Folic acid deficiency (B): Linked to neural tube defects, not cleft palate. o Maternal diabetes (C): May increase risk but are less strongly associated than anticonvulsants. 2. Prevention: o Women on anticonvulsants should consult their physician to balance seizure control with teratogenic risks. o Preconception folic acid supplementation is recommended to reduce overall congenital anomaly risk.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is most commonly performed in a child with cleft palate to assess the risk of hearing problems?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Impedance audiometry (tympanometry) 1. Hearing Problems in Cleft Palate: o Children with cleft palate are prone to middle ear effusion and conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube dysfunction. 2. Investigations: o Impedance audiometry (tympanometry) assesses middle ear function and detects effusion. o Pure tone audiometry (A) and BERA (E) are used for detailed hearing evaluation but are not the first step. o Otoacoustic emissions (B) assess cochlear function, not middle ear. o CT scan of the temporal bone (D) is not routinely required
